user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_get_free:
```c
size_t
MHD_pool_get_free (struct MemoryPool *pool)
{
  mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->pos == ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->pos));
#ifdef MHD_ASAN_POISON_ACTIVE
  if ((pool->end - pool->pos) <= _MHD_RED_ZONE_SIZE)
    return 0;
#endif /* MHD_ASAN_POISON_ACTIVE */
  return (pool->end - pool->pos) - _MHD_RED_ZONE_SIZE;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
mhd_assert (pool->pos == ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->pos));
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the statement calls mhd_assert and ROUND_TO_ALIGN with pool->pos; neither is shown calling MHD_pool_get_free, so there is no direct or indirect recursion. A violation would only occur if either mhd_assert or ROUND_TO_ALIGN expanded/implemented to call MHD_pool_get_free (or call another routine that eventually calls it). For example, if ROUND_TO_ALIGN(x) were implemented as a function that (directly or indirectly) invoked MHD_pool_get_free, that would create an indirect self-call and violate Rule 17.2.
